Authors:
Willem Man in ’t Veld, Karin C.H.M Rosendahl, Patricia van
Rijswick, Johan P. Meffert, Marcel westenberg, Bart van de Vossenberg,
Geoffrey Denton, Fons A.J. van Kuik
Title:
Phytophthora terminalis sp. nov. and Phytophthora occultans
sp. nov., two new pathogens of ornamental plants in Europe.
Keywords:
Asian radiation, Ã-tubulin, CoxI, EF-1Î±, ITS,
taxonomy
Abstract:
In the last decade a number of Phytophthora strains was
isolated from diseased Pachysandra terminalis plants suffering stem base
and root rot and originating from the Netherlands and Belgium. Based on
ITS sequences detected only in symptomatic root tissue of Sarcococca in
Great Britain since 2007, it could be deduced that Sarcococca also
harbors the same Phytophthora species. All isolates had a felty colony
pattern, contained semi-papillate sporangia and globose oogonia and had
a maximum temperature for growth of ~27 C. Phylogenetic analysis using
ITS, CoxI and EF-1Î± revealed that all sequences for each locus were
identical and unique and clustered in subclade 2a. In addition, a number
of Phytophthora strains was isolated from diseased Buxus sempervirens
plants originating from the Netherlands and Belgium, that were suffering
from stem base and root rot, whereas some strains were also isolated
from Acer palmatum, Choisya and Taxus in Great Britain. All isolates had
a stellate colony pattern, possessed larger semi-papillate sporangia and
smaller globose oogonia than the isolates from Pachysandra, and had a
maximum temperature for growth of ~30 C. Phylogenetic analysis using
ITS, CoxI and EF-1Î± showed that all sequences for each locus were
identical and unique and grouped in subclade 2a as well. Sequence
analysis using Ã-tubulin showed that both taxa contained identical
sequences, that were also identical to P. himalsilva. P. himalsilva
originates from Asia suggesting that all three taxa recently radiated in
Asia. Pathogenicity trials with isolates from Pachysandra on this host
and with isolates from Buxus on this host caused disease symptoms on
their respective hosts and after reisolation the identity of the
pathogens was confirmed in both cases, thus fulfilling the postulates of
Koch.
